entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 22 at 1:51PM EDT until August 22 at 2:45PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast Florida, including the following county, Miami-Dade.
* WHEN...Until 245 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 151 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Doral, Sweetwater, Tamiami, Kendale Lakes, University Park, Fountainbleau, Olympia Heights, Everglades National Park, Kendall West and Fiu South Campus. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 22 at 11:49AM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division and the Wyoming Department of Health.
WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
WHERE...Sheridan County, Wyoming.
WHEN...Now through 1 PM MDT Friday.
IMPACTS...Heavy smoke from area fires including the House Draw Fire.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sheridan Foothills

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM MDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued August 22 at 11:45AM MDT until August 24 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph expected.
* WHERE...Western Millard and Juab Counties, Great Salt Lake Desert and Mountains, Tooele and Rush Valleys, and Southwest Utah.
* WHEN...From 6 AM Friday to 10 PM MDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects and a few power outages may result. Strong winds and rough waves on the Great Salt Lake will create hazardous conditions for small craft.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds will initially develop in more localized southerly downslope prone areas like the north ends of the Oquirrh and Stansbury Mountains early Friday morning, then become more widespread Friday afternoon. Stronger winds will become more localized to southerly downslope areas again Friday night into early Saturday before becoming more widespread again Saturday afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Great Salt Lake Desert and Mountains; Tooele and Rush Valleys; Western Millard and Juab Counties; Southwest Utah

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM FRIDAY TO 10 PM MDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 22 at 11:24AM MDT until August 25 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Salt Lake City has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from noon Friday to midnight MDT Saturday night.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 478 Salt Lake Desert, Fire Weather Zone 492 Central Utah West Desert and Fire Weather Zone 495 Color Country West Desert.
* WINDS...Southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph. Winds will diminish Friday night but redevelop on Saturday.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 9 percent. Poor overnight recoveries to around 20%
* IMPACTS...Critical fire weather conditions are expected. Any new fire starts or existing fires may spread rapidly.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Salt Lake Desert; Central Utah West Desert; Color Country West Desert

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON FRIDAY TO MIDNIGHT MDT SATURDAY NIGHT FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 478, 492, AND 495

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 22 at 11:10AM MDT until August 22 at 12:45PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
At 1110 AM MDT, Park Ranger reported flooding and Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across Zion National Park. Between 0.5 and 1.5 inches of rain has fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar and Park Ranger observed.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, roadways, typically dry washes, and slot canyons.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Zion National Park.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 22 at 10:19AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...Most of northwest Wyoming.
* WHEN...Now through 1 PM MDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from the Fish Creek Fire on Togwotee Pass continues to be observed across much of western and central Wyoming. The smoke is limiting visibilities at times.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Jackson Hole; Upper Wind River Basin

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 22 at 10:02AM CDT by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Arkansas...
Cache River Near Patterson affecting Woodruff and Jackson Counties.
For the Cache River...including Patterson...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Cache River near Patterson.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Low swampy timberland along the river begins to flood. Flood gates should be closed and equipment moved out of the low grounds along the river and tributaries.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:15 AM CDT Thursday the stage was 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage Thursday morning, Aug 22, and continue rising to a crest of 9.5 feet Sunday morning, Aug 25. The river will begin falling early Monday morning, Aug 26, falling to 9.3 feet by Tuesday morning, Aug 27. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jackson, AR; Woodruff, AR

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 22 at 4:21AM PDT until August 22 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
A strong storm system for this time of the year will move into the area Thursday bringing moderate to strong winds. Because the best chance for precipitation will remain west of the Cascades, relative humidities will be low and this in combination with winds could result in critical conditions.
* IMPACTS...Strong winds combined with critically low relative humidity can lead to the rapid growth and spread of new and existing fires. Outdoor burning is banned during fire season.
* AFFECTED AREA...The eastern half of California Fire Weather Zone 285, this includes Alturas. The eastern part of part of Oregon Fire weather zone 625, this includes Adel and Alkali Lake.

* HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 22 at 3:23AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality is forecasting an Ozone Advisory Day for East Baton Rouge, West Baton Rouge, Livingston, Ascension, Iberville, and Pointe Coupee Parishes, .
The Air Quality Index indicates that ozone will be at the Orange level, which is unhealthy for sensitive groups. Increasing ozone levels may cause unhealthy air quality during afternoon hours. Active children and adults, the elderly, and people with respiratory diseases such as asthma should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion.
Please take whatever voluntary steps you can to reduce emissions that contribute to ozone formation. Drive less and make sure your automobile is in good working condition. Make sure your gas cap is tight. Wait until after 6 PM to refuel your vehicle and use gas powered lawn equipment. More information about current air quality and what you can do to help prevent ozone formation is available at the D E Q website www.deq.louisiana.gov/enviroflash or by calling 8 6 6 8 9 6 5 3 3 7.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pointe Coupee; Iberville; West Baton Rouge; East Baton Rouge; Northern Livingston; Southern Livingston; Western Ascension; Eastern Ascension

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT CDT TONIGHT

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 3:53PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
AQASHV
The Texas Commission of Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has declared an Ozone Action Day for the Tyler...Longview...Marshall areas of East Texas for Thursday.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Tyler-Longview area on Thursday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking or riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
If required...the next Ozone Action Day notice will be issued by 300 pm on Thursday.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: the Facts (https://www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html)
EPA Air Now (https://www.airnow.gov/?reportingArea=Tyler-Longview- Marshall&stateCode=TX)
Take Care of Texas (https://takecareoftexas.org/hot-wire/what-ozone-action-day)

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 3:34PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality is forecasting an Ozone Advisory Day for Orleans, Jefferson, St John the Baptist, St Charles, St Bernard, St Tammany, and Plaquemines Parishes tomorrow.
The Air Quality Index indicates that ozone will be at the Orange level, which is unhealthy for sensitive groups. Increasing ozone levels may cause unhealthy air quality during afternoon hours. Active children and adults, the elderly, and people with respiratory diseases such as asthma should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion.
Please take whatever voluntary steps you can to reduce emissions that contribute to ozone formation. Drive less and make sure your automobile is in good working condition. Make sure your gas cap is tight. Wait until after 6 PM to refuel your vehicle and use gas powered lawn equipment. More information about current air quality and what you can do to help prevent ozone formation is available at the D E Q website www.deq.louisiana.gov/enviroflash or by calling 8 6 6 8 9 6 5 3 3 7.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 21 at 1:56PM MDT until August 22 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS, LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY AND UNSTABLE CONDITIONS THURSDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING IN IDAHO FIRE WEATHER ZONES 402, 403 AND 421...
.Dry southwest flow will bring gusty winds and low relative humidities to the region on Thursday. These conditions will be accompanied by a dry and unstable air mass aloft which could lead to plume-dominated growth on existing wildfires.
The National Weather Service in Boise issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds, low relative humidities, and unstable conditions, which is in effect from 3 PM to 9 PM MDT Thursday.
* Affected Area...In Idaho, Fire Weather Zones 402 Eastern Payette National Forest, 403 Northern Boise National Forest and 421 Southern Boise National Forest/Western Sawtooth National Forest.
* Timing...From 3 PM to 9 PM MDT Thursday.
* Winds...South 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* Relative Humidity...8 to 15 percent.
* Temperatures...75 to 90.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Payette National Forest; Northern Boise National Forest; Southern Boise/Western Sawtooth NF, including the Camas Prairie

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 1:45PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...The Wind River Basin and portions of the Tetons and Wind River Mountains.
* WHEN...1 PM MDT Wednesday through 1 PM MDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from the Fish Creek Fire near Togwotee Pass will limit visibility and lead to poor air quality.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Jackson Hole; Upper Wind River Basin

entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Reno has issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds and low humidity, which is in effect from 2 PM to 10 PM PDT Thursday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* CHANGES...Fire Weather Watch upgraded to a Red Flag Warning.
* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zone 420 Northern Sierra Front including Carson City, Douglas, Storey, Southern Washoe, Western Lyon and and Far Southern Lassen Counties.
* Winds...Southwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph. Localized higher gusts to 40 mph in wind prone areas.
* Humidity...13 to 18%
* Duration...2 to 5 hours.
* Impacts...The combination of gusty winds and low humidity can cause fire to rapidly grow in size and intensity before first responders can contain them.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 21 at 2:24PM EDT until August 23 at 2:15PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report areas of flooding and gradually rising water across portions of Southeast Madison County. Areas of specific concern are near Lee Sink affecting SE Magnolia Drive as well as other flooded areas southward toward Interstate 10 and east of State Road 53. Flood waters are gradually shifting eastward toward the Suwannee River. Note that flood waters are not impacting access to or travel on Interstate 10 or US Highway 90.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida in Southeast Madison County.
* WHEN...Until 215 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 215 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist into at least early next week as water runoff from Hurricane Debby continues. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 215 PM EDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 20 at 11:19AM EDT until August 26 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding from the Intracoastal Waterway
* WHERE...A portion of northeast South Carolina, including the following county, Horry.
* WHEN...Until noon EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...At 17 feet...flooding of about three dozen ground level structures on Rosewood Drive, Star Creek Circle, and Recreation Road worsens and about 24 more ground level structures begin to flood. Flooding expands on Rosewood Drive, River Road, Ed Smith Avenue, Creekside Drive, Mill Creek Road, Smith Boulevard, Folly Lane, John Henry Lane, Star Creek Circle, West Oak Circle and Roberta Lane with residences isolated. Zeddie Lane, Renata Lane, and Earls Road begin to flood. Lowest yards along Shem Creek Circle begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1106 AM EDT, The Waterway at Socastee is currently peaking between 16.5 and 16.7 feet. The water levels are not expected to fall below 15 ft until next Monday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
